instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message:
By following the schematic best I could and with the help of two other posts on this forum:
- [url]https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/19199-solved-820-4924-no-backlight[/url]
- [url]https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards/forum/board-repair-troubleshooting/24554-solved-820-4924-no-backlight[/url]

I am stuck.

Unit POSTs, loads the OS (visible with flashlight) and passes all but one hardware test. Hardware test shows "there may be an issue with the display". Thanks Apple, helpful!

[B]+[/B] Tested with good 2015 display, also no backlight.
[B]+[/B] Measurements are taken with display connected and lid open.
[B]+[/B] I suspect minor liquid damage (small trace on bottom case) but board is clean, like new clean.

(Sorry, these are not in order, I kinda jumped all over the place)

[B]R1430[/B] = 3.34V
[B]R8331[/B] = 3.34V
[B]U7700[/B] = 3.34V pin 17 [B]//[/B] 0V pin 2
[B]Q7701[/B] = 023.1mv slowly rising pin 5 [B]//[/B] 0V all other pins
[B]R7742[/B] = 3.34V pin 2
PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT = 007.1mv on [B]D7710[/B], [B]C7760[/B]-[B]65[/B], [B]C8300[/B], [B]C8303[/B] [COLOR=#FF0000](these should read 53V correct?)[/COLOR]
[B]L7710[/B] = 020.4mv slowly rising
[B]Q7700[/B] = 12.44V pin 3 [B]//[/B] 12.6V pin 4 [B]//[/B] 020.1 slowly rising all other pins
[B]F7700[/B] = 12.6V both pins
[B]PPBUS_G3H[/B] = 12.6V
[B]R5171[/B] = 3.4V (SMC_LID)
[B]J8300[/B] = 008.2mv pin 1 [B]//[/B] 5.1V pin 30 (connector looks good, all pins connected)
[B]C7700[/B] = 12.6V
[B]R7701[/B] = 12.6V
[B]R7731[/B]/[B]32[/B] = 007.1mv with very slight variations up and down.

Any help appreciated :)

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: Did you inspect for corrosion under the lp8550 chip for water damage ?

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: Where would I find lp8550? Doesn't show on schematic or bv. I went over the entire board several times, it's pretty much like new.

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: Check both I2C_BKLT traces for continuity from connector to U7700.

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: Continuity is ok from pins 3 and 4 to R7750-R7753 and probe points to U7700 (I see no means of measuring actual U7700 pins without removing chip).

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: Diode mode on pins 3 and 4?

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: Ah yes... Diode mode. The one thing I've never used and am unable to figure out how to use. Maybe my meter doesn't do/support it? [ATTACH alt="Click image for larger version  Name:	IMG_8661.JPG Views:	4 Size:	4.78 MB ID:	27394" type="full" width="30%"]27394._xfImport[/ATTACH] Been meaning to ask how to do that. Only diode symbol I see is the setting I put it on to check continuity so all I get is beeping, no readout.

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: Ah, figured it out :) Will make the measurements tomorrow.

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message:
Pin 3: 0V
Pin 4: .0L

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: Both of those measurements make no sense or there is something seriously wrong or are you measuring with power applied?

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: I probably messed it up. Link to a good guide on "how to diode mode" please?

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: I have no link. Probably in one of Louis's videos that you should just go and watch all of them. Google should also turn up enough hints.

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message:
Alright measured again.
Diode mode on pin 3 = 0.000 - 0.001V
Diode mode on pin 4 = 0.001 - 0.002V

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: I doubt that both pins would be shorted to GND.....possible but highly unlikely. Or are you measuring with power applied?

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: I measured several times to be sure. No power is applied at the time.

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: Pins 1-10 on the LCD connector on diode mode?

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message:
Not sure if ok, someone maybe can compare with another board, your diode mode on pin3 seems high.

R7750 measuring 0 ohms?
And resistance of R7751?

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message:
R7750 is 000.2 ohm
R7751 is 000.1 ohm

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: Diode mode on R7750/51?

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: 0.857 on R7750, 0.570 on R7751 both sides.

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: Pin 4 at .857 is too high, so bad trace or bad U7700.

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: I have continuity from pin 3 all the way to U7700. U7700 was replaced and issue persisted.

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message:
Problem inside lcd connector?

Are you sure you are probing the 3rd leg of connector not the pad?

If you have a spare lcd cable you can connect it and check again diode mode from R7750 to pin 4 on the other end of cable.

EDIT: I realized and think lcd connector has nothing to do with higher diode mode value...

threads.title: 820-4924 no backlight
threads.message: I don't know. Only thing I know is that .857 is too high. So probably dead/killed U7700 again.
